Photo: Genevieve Ross, AP Image 11 of 11 Texans owner Bob McNair's donation to anti-LBGT group provokes ire 1 / 11 Back to Gallery Houston Texans owner Bob McNair is worth $3.3 billion .
Taxpayers – many of them supporters of McNair's Texans — were kind enough (read: forced) to fund 61 percen t of McNair's stadium, completed in 2002.
Total public funding for Reliant Stadium, now NRG Stadium, was $261 million, compared to $185 million in private funds.
Nearly 4 percent of Texans identify as gay/lesbian, bisexual, or transgender, while 60 percent of all Americans support same-sex marriage.
The population in Houston — which, by the way, elected Annise Parker, the first openly gay mayor of a major American metropolis — is approximately 2.19 million, which would place over 87,000 openly LBGT individuals in the city.
Why do those numbers matter when it comes to the owner of a football team?
Because a $10,000 check bearing McNair's name was just cashed by Campaign for Houston, a group vehemently opposed to Houston's Equal Rights Ordinance (HERO).
HERO opponents adamantly insist that outlawing discrimination based on gender identity could threaten the very existence, the very purity, of the city; particularly the sanctity of the public restroom .
McNair's donation is a green-tinged slap to the collective face of the rainbow assemblage of people who come to his stadium, who funded it with their own money, who helped a billionaire build a monolith dedicated to a game where men still fear to come as they are — because of individuals like McNair.
The HERO legislation protects "people in employment, housing and business services on the basis of 15 different characteristics, including sex, race, color, ethnicity, national origin, age, familial status, marital status, military status, religion, disability, sexual orientation, genetic information, gender identity and pregnancy."
Discriminating against any person on the basis of the listed traits carries a $5,000 fine.
It is, first and foremost, a law designed to promote and protect equality and those who believe in it, men like former NFL player Chris Kluwe.
Kluwe has been one of, perhaps the most, outspoken athlete advocate of LBGT rights in recent years.
A piece written by the former punter for Deadspin accused the Vikings of releasing him after eight seasons due to his vocal support of same-sex marriage.
The Vikings still deny this, but Kluwe never got another job in the NFL, though he's taken on a new one in the years since: full-time activist.
It appears McNair has walked directly into Kluwe's crosshairs, and that's a perilous place to be, even for a billionaire.
Kluwe penned a piece for The Cauldron railing against McNair for his donation to a group many believe is driven by hatred and fear.
Kluwe claws into McNair's ignorance on the situation and presents startling statistics associated with the LBGT community.
"Are you not aware that trans individuals are nine times more likely to try and kill themselves due to the odiously corrosive social views like the one you've just financially enabled?" Kluwe writes. "Have you no knowledge of the fact that LBGT youth are far more likely to experience harassment at school and home, leading to depression and ideations of self-harm — mostly due to the shortsighted wrongheadedness of privileged narcissists like yourself?"
Kluwe continues at length employing a mix of garish language, facts and personal views.
Former Astro Lance Berkman, part of McNair's camp, has focused on "the bathroom ordinance," expressing concern that the city law could open up women's restrooms, locker rooms and showers to "troubled men."
In an ad for Campaign for Houston, Berkman refers warns against "troubled men who claim to be women."
This despite the fact that the 36-page ordinance makes no mention of public restrooms, while supporters state that the edict would in no way protect predators.
Voters, those like Kluwe and those like McNair, will take to the ballots Nov. 3 to decide on HERO's fate.
McNair has more money than the collective of people who will turn out to vote in favor of HERO, and he's got powerful allies with recognizable faces and lofty platforms.
But HERO proponents have individuals like Chris Kluwe and Annise Parker, and in this fight, that might make all the difference.
